prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Special Considerations with Regard to Injunctions

head.headtext: Confidential Information Is Used as a Springboard

para.paratext: In certain circumstances, the court may grant an injunction to deprive the offending party of any advantage obtained by wrongfully using confidential information. The court in Terrapin Ltd. v. Builders' Supply Co. (Hayes) Ltd.,[1] as applied by Spence J. in Slavutych v. Baker,[2] described the “springboard principle” as follows:

“… a person who has obtained information in confidence is not allowed to use it as a springboard for activities detrimental to the person who made the confidential communication, and springboard it remains even when all the features have been published or can be ascertained by actual inspection by any member of the public.”

An injunction in a case like this will be granted for such time as it would otherwise have taken the offending party to obtain the confidential information by lawful means.[3] This principle is based on the fact that there has been a breach of confidence, and the innocent party should be placed in the same position he or she would have been in had the offending party not appropriated the confidential information. The offending party will not normally be prevented from competing with the moving party, but only from taking advantage of the moving party's confidential information. The offending party will be prevented from competing with the moving party only if the offending party owed a fiduciary duty to the moving party.[4]
In Potters-Ballotini Ltd. v. Weston-Baker,[5] Lord Denning held that:

Although a man must not use [confidential] information as a springboard to get a start over others, nevertheless that springboard does not last for ever. If he does not use it, a time may come when so much has happened that he can no longer be restrained.[6]
One of the issues that should be considered by the courts in deciding how long to prevent the defendant from competing with the plaintiff is deterrence.[7]

The springboard doctrine also applies to information that is part public and part confidential, or to information that, having been disclosed in confidence to certain recipients, then falls into the public domain. In Seager v. Copydex Ltd.,[8] Lord Denning held:

When the information is mixed, being partly public and partly private, then the recipient must take special care to use only the material which is in the public domain. He should go to the public source and get it: or, at any rate, not be in a better position than if he had gone to the public source.

In CCS Corp. v. Secure Energy Services Inc.,[9] the defendant Pembina brought an application for summary judgment in regard to certain allegations in the Re-Amended Statement of Claim of CCS. CCS and Pembina, and the defendant Secure were competitors in the oilfield waste disposal industry. Secure was formed by Amirault and Steinke, working together with the defendants Myrheim, Wieler and Perras, all of whom were former employees of CCS. CCS alleged that, in 2005, Pembina entered into detailed negotiations with CCS about business opportunities that the two corporations could develop together, but shortly thereafter Pembina encouraged Steinke and Amirault to instead establish Secure as a competitor to CCS. CCS alleged that Pembina conspired with Steinke, Amirault, and the other former CCS employees, as well as Secure's full-time contractor Newman, also a former CCS employee, to use CCS confidential information in developing a Pembina/Secure Joint Venture. That Joint Venture took the form of a Full Service Terminal located near La Glace, Alberta, directly across the road from an existing CCS FST. Moreover, CCS alleged that Secure, its senior employee Myrheim, and Newman participated in the supply and use of CCS confidential process and instrumentation drawings to Triumph, a corporation engaged by Secure to design the La Glace FST.[10]

The court concluded that Triumph had some access to CCS confidential information in the form of PFD and P&IDs for CCS facilities, and specifically its Grande Prairie FST. Indeed, certain elements of the design for the La Glace FST were directly copied from drawings that were the property of CCS. There was some evidence upon which a court could conclude that Secure, through its officers Myrheim and Perras, was aware that Triumph was relying CCS drawings in the design of the La Glace FST, and there was evidence upon which a court could conclude that Secure and its joint venture partner Pembina benefited from Triumph's use of CCS confidential information as a result of the significantly reduced costs associated with the design of the La Glace FST. Pembina also had in its possession a set of P&IDs that CCS described as containing confidential CCS designs. The existence in Pembina's possession of P&IDs that may contain confidential CCS information, together with the notes of Pembina's engineer recommending changes was at least some evidence that would suggest that Pembina took some role in the design of the La Glace FST.[11]

A “springboard” claim is in essence a claim for breach of confidence. Pembina argued that even if CCS established an unlawful taking of its information, there was no evidence that Pembina had any knowledge thereof and, therefore, the claim for breach of confidence, as against Pembina, should be dismissed. The court agreed that there was no evidence by which it could be concluded that Pembina had direct knowledge of an unlawful use of CCS confidential information. The best CCS could do in this regard was to suggest that Pembina should be affixed with constructive notice of the misuse of CCS confidential information on the basis that a reasonable person in its position should have made inquiries about the origin of the information used to design the La Glace FST. This was not a sound basis for imputing knowledge of the misuse of CCS confidential information to Pembina. To the extent that there was evidence that would support an extension of liability to Pembina for the use of CCS confidential information, it was on the basis of its joint and/or vicarious liability as partner or joint venturer with Secure.[12]

There was no evidence to support the allegation that Pembina persuaded, induced or procured Secure to unlawfully use CCS confidential information. There was, however, some evidence upon which a court might conclude that Triumph had access to and used CCS Confidential Information in the design of the La Glace FST, and some evidence upon which a court could conclude that the confidential information was provided to it by former CCS employees with the knowledge of Secure. The question that remained was whether, despite an absence of any direct evidence to the effect that Pembina knew that Triumph and Secure were making improper use of CCS confidential information, liability for this improper use could be extended to Pembina. CCS alleged that Pembina was liable because (a) Pembina and Secure were partners, and; (b) even if Pembina and Secure were not partners, policy considerations of compensation, deterrence and loss internalization warranted extending liability to Pembina.[13]

Insofar as the CCS claim related to the use of its confidential information in the design of the La Glace FST, there was some evidence that: (a) confidential CCS information was used by Newman and Triumph in the design of the La Glace FST; (b) Secure, via its officer Myrheim, and via Newman himself, was aware that Triumph had obtained and was using the confidential CCS information; (c) Secure and Pembina reaped material benefits from the use of CCS confidential information because it significantly expedited the design of the La Glace FST.[14]

The relationship between Secure and Pembina was such that the parties might be held to be jointly or vicariously liable for the use of CCS confidential information. The CCS claim in this regard had merit and should not be summarily dismissed.[15]

Pembina was entitled to summary judgment in respect of the following: Pembina did not assist the Former Employee Defendants to use CCS Confidential Information to set up a competing business with the intention of causing a breach of the Former Employee Defendants' employment contracts or other legal obligations to CCS; and Pembina did not have direct knowledge of an unlawful use of CCS Confidential Information and as such was not directly liable for breach of confidence or for the use of CCS Confidential Information as a “springboard”. Pembina was not entitled to summary judgment in respect of the CCS claims that Pembina was jointly or vicariously liable with Secure in the unlawful use of CCS Confidential Information in the design of the La Glace FST. To put it another way: Pembina was entitled to summary dismissal of all CCS claims against it, except for the vicarious liability claims arising out of the alleged use of CCS Confidential Information by Secure.[16]

In Nlogic Inc. v. Microtherapy Inc.,[17] the applicant did not refer to any cases where the springboard doctrine had been applied in the absence of a breach of confidence, nor did the applicant discuss in any detail how the doctrine, accepting it could be applicable to a breach of contract case would be applied in such a context. The Court's conclusions that the respondent was not restricted in its marketing efforts during the winding-up period, that the respondent did not engage in marketing activity during the winding-up period, and that the respondent did not breach the AirWare agreement by developing RADIUS during the term of the agreement rendered unnecessary a conclusion with respect to entitlement to springboard relief but the Court nonetheless proceed to conduct the analysis in the event it was incorrect in making these findings.[18]

The applicant sought an injunction preventing the respondent from marketing its software product known as RADIUS for 12 months beyond the effective termination of the AirWare agreement. Further, the applicant argued that the court ought to grant an injunction for an additional seven months because, it was argued, the respondent had an additional seven months, from the time it converted AirWare C# into RADIUS until the hearing of the application to work toward converting the applicant's clients to RADIUS. The applicant alleged that the respondent had taken a head start allowing it to springboard ahead of the applicant. The applicant relied on the Supreme Court of Canada's decision in Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd. (1999), 167 D.L.R. (4th) 577, [1999] 1 S.C.R. 142, [1999] 5 W.W.R. 751, 59 B.C.L.R. (3d) 1, 117 B.C.A.C. 161, 191 W.A.C. 161, 42 B.L.R. (2d) 159, 43 B.L.R. (2d) 159, 83 C.P.R. (3d) 289, 235 N.R. 30, [2000] F.S.R. 491, 1999 CarswellBC 77, 1999 CarswellBC 78, 85 A.C.W.S. (3d) 166, [1999] S.C.J. No. 6 (S.C.C.), wherein Justice Binnie explained the springboard doctrine as follows:

The “springboard” or “head start” concept descends from the judgment of Roxburgh J. in Terrapin Ltd. v. Builders' Supply Co. (Hayes) Ltd., [1967] R.P.C. 375 (Ch. D. 1959), aff'd [1960] R.P.C. 128 (C.A.), at p. 391:

As I understand it, the essence of this branch of the law, whatever the origin of it may be, is that a person who has obtained information in confidence is not allowed to use it as a spring-board for activities detrimental to the person who made the confidential communication, and spring-board it remains even when all the features have been published or can be ascertained by actual inspection by any member of the public.[19]

The most significant problem with the relief requested was that the evidentiary record failed to demonstrate the applicant's assertion that the respondent had taken a head start and that the applicant had lost an opportunity. There was no evidence of a springboard advantage, no evidence that the applicant's efforts in developing and marketing a new product had been impeded by the stated actions of the respondent, and no evidence of any harm to the applicant caused by the respondent's conduct. Even if the springboard doctrine was applicable to the facts of the case, the applicant failed to prove a loss sufficient to support their choice of remedy.[20]

In Pat's Off-Road Transport v. Campbell,[21] the Plaintiff ran a company providing “hot oil services”, a truck and truck-mounted piece of equipment used to heat water stored in tanks on oil well drilling sites, to the oil industry. Over a 20-year period culminating in 2001, the principal of the plaintiff developed, by trial and error, and with the investment of a great deal of time and money, a truck mounted heating unit that was commercially advantageous over its competitors. The Plaintiff claimed that this technology was being kept secret from the public and its competition, and the technology was a trade secret.[22]

In April 2001, the Plaintiff hired Campbell as a truck driver. He was trained to operate, maintain and clean the trucks with the mounted heating units. Campbell's employment was terminated by the Plaintiff on July 3, 2003. Two years after Campbell left the Plaintiff's employment, he developed and built a truck mounted heating unit that was virtually identical to that of the Plaintiff.[23]

The trial judge observed that at a minimum, Campbell used, as part of his recipe for making his own hot oiler unit, some private information from the Plaintiff. The building of this unit was not a simple process. Campbell acknowledged that much of the design of the plaintiff's truck was unique. Notwithstanding all of his research on the internet, his reverse engineering and his consultation with suppliers and manufacturers, he could not have built his unit without the information and knowledge gained from working with the Plaintiff. Campbell's knowledge of the process created by the plaintiff's principal was the springboard which lead to the construction of his unit.[24]

In LAC Minerals, Justice Sopinka stated that the test for whether the communications were made in confidence was “the reasonable man test”. The trial judge concluded that the reasonable man would see an “equitable obligation of confidence”. The plaintiff's principal acted in a manner to keep the fruits of his labour confidential. As unsophisticated as it was, without all the formal legal protection of confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements, it was his intention keep the intricacies of his unit to himself.[25]

By taking the confidential information that he gained while employed at the Plaintiff, Campbell clearly used that as a “springboard” to build his own unit. This information was confidential, it was intended to be confidential, and Cody Campbell's use of it was unauthorized. Campbell personally and through his company breached his duty of confidence to the Plaintiff.[26]

The trial judge was not satisfied that the Plaintiff had set out sufficient facts and thereby met the legal test to prove a breach of fiduciary duty. In order to find that a fiduciary duty exists, the Court must look at the effect on the Plaintiff's business when Campbell left, and shortly thereafter. The Plaintiff was forced to find another driver and train that person. The Plaintiff terminated a skilful employee, but the challenge of finding someone as skilful is not the same as having the entire corporate operation placed at Campbell's mercy. Unlike other cases where corporations were at a loss as to how to use their own policy or how to contact their client's corporate accounts, life went on at the Plaintiff's business as it had before. Campbell may have been a good and efficient employee but he was not “essential” or “key”, and his departure did not cause the Plaintiff to be vulnerable or at the mercy of Cody Campbell's discretion or power.[27]

Having found against Campbell on the basis of a breach of the duty of confidence, the trial judge observed that there was no actual monetary loss suffered by the Plaintiff. In fact, the Plaintiff's sales had increased considerably. There was no expert evidence led on the Defendants' gain. The onus is on the Plaintiff to establish on the basis of credible evidence its damages. Allowing Campbell and his company no penalty by way of damages even though his company made money by misappropriating his former employer's confidential information could not be countenanced. The corporate Defendant earned a net income of $39,693.00 for the year end of May 31, 2007. The trial judge imputed income of approximately the same for the last year of operation of the corporate defendant. Damages were awarded to the Plaintiff in the amount of $80,000.[28]
